elements.content: A unique metal–organic complex (MOC) with formula [Eu2(tpbpc)4·CO3·4H2O]·DMF·solvent (Htpbpc = 4′-[4,2′;6′,4″]-terpyridin-4′-yl-biphenyl-4-carboxylic acid) has been successfully constructed under solvothermal conditions. The Eu complex, as proved by structural analysis, exhibits a fascinating 1D linear-type chain structure which is further extended to a 3D H-bonded supramolecular framework. The luminescent investigations confirm that the emission behavior of the Eu complex possesses excellent water stability and pH stability, and it is the first example of a MOC-based fluorescent probe with high selectivity, high sensitivity, and low detection limit, targeting Cr­(III) and Cr­(VI) (CrO4 2–/Cr2O7 2–) ions in aqueous solution. Importantly, the luminescence can be fast and simple, regenerated in detecting CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– ions. Furthermore, the simple fluorescent-based test paper was successfully prepared and provided a reliable and visual detection of Cr3+, CrO4 2–, and Cr2O7 2– ions in daily applications.

elements.content:
This paper was published on the Web on March 20, 2017, with minor errors in Figures 6 and 7. The corrected version was reposted on March 22, 2017.

Introduction

Chromium is an important element for people and exists in two common oxidation states of Cr­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions. The toxicity of chromium in different valence is quite different. Cr­(III) ion is an important biological trace element as well as widely used in industry production, whereas excessive Cr­(III) ions in the body can combine with DNA, hence leading to mutations or malignant cells. In addition, Cr­(VI) species are poisonous pollutants to ecological environmental and biological systems due to their broad utilization in modern industry and agriculture, and it has been classified as a serious pollutant by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Additionally, long-term exposure to Cr­(VI) ions, even at low concentrations, can cause several adverse health effects such as allergic reactions, hereditary genetic defects, and even lung cancers. Excessive hexavalent chromium (more than 10 ppm) has a lethal effect on aquatic organisms, and the content of Cr­(VI) ions in the body must be less than 3 ppm. Therefore, it is very significant to detect chromium ions sensitively and rapidly in water or comestible resources, which is meaningful to environmental protection and food security. Many analysis techniques, such as chromatography, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, electrochemical methods, atomic absorption spectrometry, and synchrotron radiation X-ray spectrometry, have been used to detect chromium ions; however, these methods are often restricted by time-consuming, sample pretreatment, complicated instruments, and high cost. Therefore, it is necessary to develop time-saving, facile, convenient, and low-cost methods for chromium ions detection. Recently, fluorescence-based chemical sensors have been regarded as promising and compelling alternatives for detecting ions due to their abilities to provide an instantaneous, remote detection, visual, and economical approach for online monitoring without redundant pretreatment of the sample.

elements.content: Luminescent metal–organic complexes (MOCs) not only display prominent optical properties but also possess tunable structures, structural rigidity, and well-defined topologies; their delicate structures endow it witht he ability to serve as a functional material for selective sensing. MOC-based luminescent materials acting as fluorescent probes for pollutant detection and recognition, such as cations, anions, small molecules, organic solvents, and poisonous gases, have attracted considerable attention because of its operability, repeatability, quick response time, high sensitivity, and high selectivity to specific guests and so on, which demonstrate that MOC-based luminescent materials are excellent sensory devices. Compared to transition metals, lanthanide metal–organic complexes as luminescence sensors have received more and more attention recently owing to its several fascinating features, such as the sharp and characteristic emissions, large Stokes’ shift, relatively long luminescence lifetimes, and bright luminescent colors of Ln­(III) ions, especially for Eu­(III) and Tb­(III).
elements.clean_text: Luminescent metal-organic complexes (MOCs) not only display prominent optical properties but also possess tunable structures, structural rigidity, and well-defined topologies; their delicate structures endow it witht he ability to serve as a functional material for selective sensing. MOC-based luminescent materials acting as fluorescent probes for pollutant detection and recognition, such as cations, anions, small molecules, organic solvents, and poisonous gases, have attracted considerable attention because of its operability, repeatability, quick response time, high sensitivity, and high selectivity to specific guests and so on, which demonstrate that MOC-based luminescent materials are excellent sensory devices. Compared to transition metals, lanthanide metal-organic complexes as luminescence sensors have received more and more attention recently owing to its several fascinating features, such as the sharp and characteristic emissions, large Stokes' shift, relatively long luminescence lifetimes, and bright luminescent colors of Ln(III) ions, especially for Eu(III) and Tb(III).

elements.content: To date, some luminescent-based complexes have been successfully used as luminescent probes for sensing Ag+, Cd2+, Cu2+, Fe3+, acetone, DMF, and explosive nitro compounds, but only a few luminescent-based complexes for detecting Cr­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions have been achieved to date. For example, Zhu et al. reported a MOF [Eu­(Hpzbc)2(NO3)]·H2O which has been used to detect Cr (VI) ions. Ma et al. reported two polyoxovanadates-based inorganic–organic hybrid complexs [Zn5(Htrb)2(H2O)2(V5O15)2]·11H2O and [Ag3(Htrb)­(H4V5O16)]·H2O, which have been used as luminescent sensors for Cr­(III) ion, while the detection limits of these complexes are relatively high and the responsive time relatively long, which limit their practical detecting applications in low concentration and instantaneously. Recently, Liu et al. synthesized a luminescent MOF, [Zn2(TPOM)­(NH2-BDC)2]·4H2O which can be used to recognize Cr­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions in DMF and shows a low detection limit and quick response. However, DMF is not an environmental solvent and limits its practical sensing applications. To our knowledge, there has been no literature discussing the Ln–MOCs as luminescence sensors to detect chromium in different valences in aqueous solutions at the same time.

For example, Zhu et al. reported a MOF [Eu(Hpzbc)2(NO3)]⋅H2O which has been used to detect Cr (VI) ions. Ma et al. reported two polyoxovanadates-based inorganic-organic hybrid complexs [Zn5(Htrb)2(H2O)2(V5O15)2]⋅11H2O and [Ag3(Htrb)(H4V5O16)]⋅H2O, which have been used as luminescent sensors for Cr(III) ion, while the detection limits of these complexes are relatively high and the responsive time  relatively long, which limit their practical detecting applications in low concentration and instantaneously. Recently, Liu et al. synthesized a luminescent MOF, [Zn2(TPOM)(NH2-BDC)2]⋅4H2O which can be used to recognize Cr(III) and Cr(VI) ions in DMF and shows a low detection limit and quick response. However, DMF is not an environmental solvent and limits its practical sensing applications. To our knowledge, there has been no literature discussing the Ln-MOCs as luminescence sensors to detect chromium in different valences in aqueous solutions at the same time.

elements.content: On the basis of these considerations above, we choose an unexplored ligand 4′-[4,2′;6′,4″]-terpyridin-4′-yl-biphenyl-4-carboxylic acid, , which contains three pyridine rings and one carboxyl group combining with Eu­(III) through versatile coordination modes of carboxylic acid. Herein, a 1D luminescent Eu complex, [Eu2(tpbpc)4·CO3·4H2O]·DMF·solvent, has been successfully obtained via solvothermal condition, which emits bright red luminescence. Interestingly, the Eu complex is an excellent luminescence-based sensor with quantifiability, low detection limit, high sensitivity, and selectivity for detecting of Cr3+, CrO4 2–, and Cr2O7 2– ions. More importantly, this is the first example of a lanthanide metal–organic complex as a luminescence probe to detect different valences of chromium ions in aqueous solutions simultaneously.

elements.content: The ligand Htpbpc and all solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used as delivered. Fourier transform infrared spectra of the sample with a KBr pellet were carried out on a PerkinElmer Spectrum Two FT-IR spectrometer (4000–400 cm–1). Thermogravimetric analysis was measured on a NETZSCH STA409pc instrument heated from 30 to 1100 °C under nitrogen protection. X-ray diffraction patterns (PXRD) were measured on an EMPYREAN PANALYTICAL apparatus using Cu Kα radiation and recorded on crushed single crystals in the range 5–80°. The UV–vis absorption spectra were carried out on a U-3900 spectrophotometer. The fluorescence excitation and emission spectra were recorded on an Edinburgh FLS920 spectrophotometer with a 150 W xenon lamp as an excitation source equipped at room temperature. The luminescence decay curves were examined using an Edinburgh FLS920 spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

The ligand Htpbpc and all  solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used as delivered. Fourier transform infrared spectra of the sample with a KBr pellet were carried out on a PerkinElmer Spectrum Two FT-IR spectrometer (4000-400 cm-1). Thermogravimetric analysis was measured on a NETZSCH STA409pc instrument heated from 30 to 1100 °C under nitrogen protection. X-ray diffraction patterns (PXRD)  were measured on an EMPYREAN PANALYTICAL apparatus using Cu Kα radiation and recorded on crushed single crystals in the range 5-80°. The UV-vis absorption spectra were carried out on a U-3900 spectrophotometer. The fluorescence excitation and emission spectra were recorded on an Edinburgh FLS920 spectrophotometer with a 150 W xenon lamp as an excitation source equipped at room temperature. The luminescence decay curves were examined using an Edinburgh FLS920 spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Htpbpc (0.12 mmol, 0.0515 g), Eu­(NO)3·6H2O (0.05 mmol, 0.0223 g), and 8 mL of a mixed solution of alcohol (EtOH), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and deionized water (H2O) (1:1:2 in volume) were placed in a seal 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless vessel, which was heated at 120 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. The as-synthesized pink block crystals are insoluble in water and common organic solvents, washed with H2O several times, and dried in air. Yield: 0.0135 g (20.25%). Anal. Calcd for C116H87Eu2N13O16: C, 62.67; H, 3.95; N, 8.19. Found: C, 62.81; H, 4.00; N, 8.13. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1669 (s), 1593 (s), 1574 (m), 1556 (m), 1528 (s), 1392 (s), 1064 (m), 1003 (m), 825 (s), 787 (s), 740 (m), 637 (s), 506 (m).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Synthesis of [Eu2(tpbpc)4⋅CO3⋅H2O]⋅DMF⋅solvent

Htpbpc (0.12 mmol, 0.0515 g), Eu(NO)3⋅6H2O (0.05 mmol, 0.0223 g), and 8 mL of a mixed solution of alcohol (EtOH), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and deionized water (H2O) (1:1:2 in volume) were placed in a seal 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless vessel, which was heated at 120 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. The as-synthesized pink block crystals are insoluble in water and common organic solvents,  washed with H2O several times, and dried in air. Yield: 0.0135 g (20.25%). Anal. Calcd for C116H87Eu2N13O16: C, 62.67; H, 3.95; N, 8.19. Found: C, 62.81; H, 4.00; N, 8.13. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 1669 (s), 1593 (s), 1574 (m), 1556 (m), 1528 (s), 1392 (s), 1064 (m), 1003 (m), 825 (s), 787 (s), 740 (m), 637 (s), 506 (m).

elements.content: A 1 mg amount of Eu–MOF was ground and dispersed in 3 mL of H2O solution including HCl or NaOH (pH = 1, 2, ..., 13) and then sonicated for 15 min to get the suspension, which was used for luminescent measurements. After standing 1 day, the samples were filtrated and used for PXRD measurements.
elements.clean_text:
pH Stability Experiments

A 1 mg amount of Eu-MOF was ground and dispersed in 3 mL of H2O solution including HCl or NaOH (pH = 1, 2, ..., 13) and then sonicated for 15 min to get the suspension, which was used for luminescent measurements. After standing 1 day, the samples were filtrated and used for PXRD measurements.

elements.content: Several servings of 2 mg of Eu complex were dispersed in 2 mL of H2O solution and then sonicated for 15 min to get the suspension, which was used for luminescent measurements. A 200 μL amount of 1 × 10–1 M M­(NO3) n (M = K+, Na+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Zn2+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Ba2+, Cu2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Al3+, Cr3+) or 1 × 10–2 M Na y X (X = F–, Cl–, Br–, I–, SO4 2–, CO3 2–, NO3 –, OAc–, SCN–, NO2 –, PO4 3–, CrO4 2–, Cr2O7 2–) was added in the above suspension for sensing experiments. Besides, in order to study the influence of other ions for the selectively quenching response, 3 mg of Eu-MOF was immersed in 3 mL of H2O, and the suspension was divided into three equal parts. Sample 1 was added to 2.4 mL of water; the sample 2 was added to 1 × 10–1 M M n+ (M = K+... Al3+), 200 μL, in sequence, and sample 3 was added to M n+ (M = K+...Cr3+), 200 μL, in sequence. Similar experimental conditions were carried out for anions. The excitation wavelength was 343 nm, and the excitation slit and emission slit were 2.5 and 5.0 nm, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Sensing Experiments

Several servings of 2 mg of Eu complex were dispersed in 2 mL of H2O solution and then sonicated for 15 min to get the suspension, which was used for luminescent measurements. A 200 μL amount of 1 × 10-1 M M(NO3) n  (M = K+, Na+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Zn2+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Ba2+, Cu2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Al3+, Cr3+) or 1 × 10-2 M Na y X (X = F-, Cl-, Br-, I-, SO4 2-, CO3 2-, NO3 -, OAc-, SCN-, NO2 -, PO4 3-, CrO4 2-, Cr2O7 2-) was added in the above suspension for sensing experiments. Besides, in order to study the influence of other ions for the selectively quenching response, 3 mg of Eu-MOF was immersed in 3 mL of H2O, and the suspension was divided into three equal parts. Sample 1 was added to 2.4 mL of water; the sample 2 was added to 1 × 10-1 M M n+ (M = K+... Al3+), 200 μL, in sequence, and sample 3 was added to M n+ (M = K+...Cr3+), 200 μL, in sequence. Similar experimental conditions were carried out for anions. The excitation wavelength was 343 nm, and the excitation slit and emission slit were 2.5 and 5.0 nm, respectively.

elements.content: The filter paper is cut into strips of 1 cm × 2 cm, and then the strips are soaked in the dispersion of Eu complex in ethanol for 2 min. The fluorescence-based test papers are dry at room temperature, which are further immersed into different metal ions (1 × 10–2 M) and anions (1 × 10–3 M) aqueous solutions and into Cr3+, CrO4 2–, and Cr2O7 2– ions aqueous solution of different concentrations for 30 s.
elements.clean_text:
Paper-Based Fluorescent Sensor

The filter paper is cut into strips of 1 cm × 2 cm, and then the strips are soaked in the dispersion of Eu complex in ethanol for 2 min. The fluorescence-based test papers are dry at room temperature, which are further immersed into different metal ions (1 × 10-2 M) and anions (1 × 10-3 M) aqueous solutions and into Cr3+, CrO4 2-, and Cr2O7 2- ions aqueous solution of different concentrations for 30 s.

elements.content: Crystallographic data were collected on a Bruker APEX-II CCD X-ray single-crystal diffractometer at 271(2) K with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184). The empirical absorption corrections were carried out using the SADABS program. Structures were solved by direct methods and refined anisotropically by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 values using the SHELX-97 program. All H atoms were added on appropriate positions in theory using the riding model. From the difference Fourier maps of the Eu complex, a number of diffuse scattered peaks with electron density were observed, which could be attributed to the disordered solvent molecules. Attempts to model these peaks were unsuccessful because the residual electron density peaks obtained were diffused. Thus, PLATON/SQUEEZE was used to refine the structure further. Crystallographic data and refinement parameters for Eu complex are listed in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S2. Crystallographic Data for Eu complex have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Date Center with the deposition number of 1513055.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Data Collection and Refinement

Crystallographic data were collected on a Bruker APEX-II CCD X-ray single-crystal diffractometer  at 271(2) K with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184). The empirical absorption corrections were carried out using the SADABS program. Structures were solved by direct methods and refined anisotropically by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 values using the SHELX-97 program. All H atoms were added on appropriate positions in theory using the riding model. From the difference Fourier maps of the Eu complex, a number of diffuse scattered peaks with electron density were observed, which could be attributed to the disordered solvent molecules. Attempts to model these peaks were unsuccessful because the residual electron density peaks obtained were diffused. Thus, PLATON/SQUEEZE was used to refine the structure further. Crystallographic data and refinement parameters for Eu complex are listed in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S2. Crystallographic Data for Eu complex have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Date Center with the deposition number of 1513055.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that Eu complex crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P–1 and exhibits a 1D chain structure based on tetranuclear Eu­(III) units. The asymmetric unit consists of two crystallographically independent Eu­(III) ions central, four tpbpc– ligands, one CO3 2–, four coordinated water molecules, and one free DMF molecule (a). Other free solvent molecules were hard to be accurately determined because of their badly disordered structures, and the PLATON Squeeze program was further used. We speculate that the CO3 2– in the structure was generated in situ by decomposition of DMF solvent. Under solvothermal conditions, C–N bond cleavage of DMF can easily produce both dimethylamine ((CH3)2NH2) and formate (HCOOH); then the HCOOH can be readily oxidized to carbonate ion. The two Eu­(III) ions have different coordination environments (b and c). Eu1 is nonacoordinated, displaying a spherical capped square antiprism (analysis with the SHAPE software) which formed by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two ligands, three oxygen atoms from two carbonate anions, and two oxygen atoms from coordinated water molecules. While the coordination sphere of nonacoordinated Eu2 is a spherical capped square antiprism which is filled by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three ligands, three oxygen atoms from two carbonate anions, and two oxygen atoms from coordinated waters molecules. The Eu–O bond distances and O–Eu–O angles are in the range of 2.3677(15)–2.6622(17) Å and 50.63°(5)–154.45°(6), respectively, which are consistent with the values of typical ranges reported for other Eu­(III) complexes. These two crystallographically independent Eu­(III) ions are connected with each other through μ4-carbonate anion, and the distance between Eu1 and Eu2 is 4.7371 Å, as well as the angle of Eu1–O14–Eu2 is 156.57°. Additionally, Eu1 and Eu1A are connected by an O atom of the carbonate anion with a distance of 4.0831 Å and an angle of Eu1–O15–Eu1A 110.883°; moreover, to the Eu2 center, O13 of the carbonate group makes a similar connection environment between Eu2A (Eu2–Eu2A 3.9309 Å, Eu2–O13–Eu2A angle of 102.634°).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [Eu2(tpbpc)4⋅CO3⋅4H2O]⋅DMF⋅solvent

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that Eu complex crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P-1 and exhibits a 1D chain structure based on tetranuclear Eu(III) units. The asymmetric unit consists of two crystallographically independent Eu(III) ions central, four tpbpc- ligands, one CO3 2-, four coordinated water molecules, and one free DMF molecule (a). Other free solvent molecules were hard to be accurately determined because of their badly disordered structures, and the PLATON Squeeze program was further used. We speculate that the CO3 2- in the structure was generated in situ by  decomposition of DMF solvent. Under solvothermal conditions,  C-N bond cleavage of DMF can easily produce both dimethylamine ((CH3)2NH2) and formate (HCOOH); then the HCOOH can be readily oxidized to carbonate ion. The two Eu(III) ions  have different coordination environments (b and c).  Eu1 is nonacoordinated, displaying a spherical capped square antiprism (analysis with the SHAPE software) which formed by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two ligands, three oxygen atoms from two carbonate anions, and two oxygen atoms from coordinated water molecules. While the coordination sphere of nonacoordinated Eu2 is a spherical capped square antiprism which is filled by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three ligands, three oxygen atoms from two carbonate anions, and two oxygen atoms from coordinated waters molecules. The Eu-O bond distances and O-Eu-O angles are in the range of 2.3677(15)-2.6622(17) Å and 50.63°(5)-154.45°(6), respectively, which are consistent with the values of typical ranges reported for other Eu(III) complexes. These two crystallographically independent Eu(III) ions  are connected with each other through μ4-carbonate anion, and the distance between Eu1 and Eu2 is 4.7371 Å, as well as the angle of Eu1-O14-Eu2 is 156.57°. Additionally,  Eu1 and Eu1A are connected by an O atom of the carbonate anion with a distance of 4.0831 Å and an angle of Eu1-O15-Eu1A  110.883°; moreover, to the Eu2 center, O13 of the carbonate group makes a similar connection environment between Eu2A (Eu2-Eu2A 3.9309 Å, Eu2-O13-Eu2A angle of 102.634°).

elements.content: Besides, the CO3 2– moieties are in a μ4-η1η1η2η2-bridging fashion in this framework. On the basis of these coordination modes, each μ4-CO3 2– moiety connects the neighboring four Eu­(III) ions to generate a tetranuclear CO3Eu4 cluster which acts as a secondary building unit (SBU); herein, each SBU is associated with eight tpbpc– ligands and eight water molecules to exhibit a four-leaf clover-shaped motif arrangement using tpbpc– ligands as leaves (e). Furthermore, carboxylate-bridged dieuropium units are connected into a chain by μ4-CO3 2– (d). Interestingly, the tpbpc– ligand adopts two coordination modes in the 1D structure: (1) the carboxylate group adopts a μ1-η2 chelating coordination mode, and (2) the carboxylate group acts as a μ2-η1η1-bridging coordination mode, wherein the carboxylate group features a bidentate coordination mode. Either in mode 1 or mode 2, the three pyridyl groups are free and make no coordination contribution ().

Furthermore, carboxylate-bridged dieuropium units are connected into a chain by μ4-CO3 2- (d). Interestingly, the tpbpc- ligand adopts two coordination modes in the 1D structure: (1) the carboxylate group adopts a μ1-η2 chelating coordination mode, and (2) the carboxylate group acts as a μ2-η1η1-bridging coordination mode, wherein the carboxylate group features a bidentate coordination mode. Either in mode 1 or mode 2, the three pyridyl groups are free and make no coordination contribution ().

elements.content: The tpbpc– ligands are not planar; the carboxylate-containing phenyl moiety is twisted by 14.628° in mode 1 (35.718° in mode 2) from the central phenyl ring, and the dihedral angle between the central phenyl group and the central pyridyl ring is 36.150° (36.137° in mode 2). Besides, the three pyridyl rings are also not coplanar, in which the dihedral angles between the central and the terminal pyridyl rings are 29.013° and 38.671° in mode 1 (28.897° and 6.624° in mode 2), respectively.

elements.content: In addition, the adjacent 1D chain is further interconnected by the O–H···N hydrogen bonds, resulting in generation of a 3D H-bonded supramolecular network, . This structure has two 1D open parallelogram channels with approximate dimensions of 15.83 × 10.67 and 13.56 × 10.77 Å2, respectively, and these 1D channels are occupied by free DMF and water molecules. The effective free volume is 6% of the crystal volume analyzed by PLATON. Noticeably, the coordination mode of CO3 2– plays an important role in the extension of the 1D chain structure, and the O–H···N H bonding makes a major contribution to expand the 1D to 3D structure.

elements.content: The IR spectra of Htpbpc and Eu complex and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis were carried out carefully at room temperature and are presented in Figures S1 and S2, respectively. The broad band at 3650–2700 cm–1 for the Eu complex can be ascribed to the stretching bands of the hydroxyl of the water molecules. The bands at 1670 cm–1 for Eu complex correspond to the stretching bands of CO of the COO– groups. Besides, the PXRD pattern shows that all of the diffraction peaks of the Eu complex are consistent with the simulated spectra from single-crystal data, implying excellent phase purity. In addition, the sharp peaks indicate the excellent crystallinity of the as-synthesized samples.
elements.clean_text:
IR and PXRD Analysis

The IR spectra of Htpbpc and Eu complex and  powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis were carried out carefully at room temperature and are presented in Figures S1 and S2, respectively. The broad band at 3650-2700 cm-1 for the Eu complex can be ascribed to the stretching bands of the hydroxyl of the water molecules. The bands at 1670 cm-1 for Eu complex correspond to the stretching bands of CO of the COO- groups. Besides, the PXRD pattern shows that all of the diffraction peaks of the Eu complex are consistent with the simulated spectra from single-crystal data, implying  excellent phase purity. In addition, the sharp peaks indicate the excellent crystallinity of the as-synthesized samples.

elements.content: To identify the stability of the 1D complex, TGA measurement has been carried out under N2 protection and is shown in Figure S3. The weightlessness curve has three distinct parts. First, the weight loss of 7.70% (calculated 7.77%) from 115 to 190 °C is due to the loss of unordered water and its internal DMF molecules. Second, the weight loss of 2.87% (calculated 3.08%) in the temperature range between 345 and 410 °C corresponds to the loss of four coordinated water molecules. Finally, the structure begins to collapse from 460 °C and does not stop until heating to 1100 °C, owing to decomposition of tpbpc– ligands, and the ultimate residue can be assigned to formation of Eu2O3. On the basis of the calculation, there are approximately six guest water molecules in the structure.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Properties

To identify the stability of the 1D complex,  TGA measurement has been carried out under N2 protection and is shown in Figure S3. The weightlessness curve has three distinct parts. First, the weight loss of 7.70% (calculated 7.77%) from 115 to 190 °C is due to the loss of unordered water and its internal DMF molecules. Second, the weight loss of 2.87% (calculated 3.08%) in the temperature range between 345 and 410 °C corresponds to the loss of four coordinated water molecules. Finally, the structure begins to collapse from 460 °C and does not stop until heating to 1100 °C, owing to  decomposition of tpbpc- ligands, and the ultimate residue can be assigned to  formation of Eu2O3. On the basis of the calculation, there are approximately six guest water molecules in the structure.

elements.content: The fluorescence measurements of the samples after treating with various pH conditions or soaking in aqueous solutions with different times were recorded at room temperature; as shown in and S5, the fluorescence intensities of samples are almost unaltered after treating with different pH values in the range of 3–13 or soaking in aqueous solution for 10 days. The corresponding PXRD patterns were recorded and are shown in Figure S4, which agrees well with the as-synthesized sample, revealing retention of the framework of Eu complex after different pH (pH = 3–13) and long time water treatment. Results indicated the excellent pH stability and water stability of the Eu complex.

pH and Water Stability Properties

The fluorescence measurements of the samples after treating with various pH conditions or soaking in aqueous solutions with different times were recorded at room temperature; as shown in  and S5, the fluorescence intensities of samples are almost unaltered after treating with different pH values in the range of 3-13 or soaking in aqueous solution for 10 days. The corresponding PXRD patterns were recorded and are shown in Figure S4, which agrees well with the as-synthesized sample, revealing  retention of the framework of Eu complex after different pH (pH = 3-13) and long time water treatment. Results indicated the excellent pH stability and water stability of the Eu complex.

elements.content: The luminescence excitation and emission spectra of the Htpbpc ligand and Eu complex have been measured in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure S6, the free Htpbpc ligands show a broad emission peak around 490 nm (λex = 338 nm), which can be ascribed to the π → π* transitions. Furthermore, the 1D Eu complex displays bright magenta luminescence under UV irradiation; as shown in , Eu complex exhibits an obvious peak with a maximum value at 414 nm besides Eu characteristic peaks upon excitation at 343 nm. Comparing with the emission for free Htpbpc ligand, there is a blue shift of approximately 76 nm, which can be belong to the ligand to ligand charge transfer. Besides, the luminescence spectra display five emission peaks at 580, 592, 618, 653, and 698 nm corresponding to the 5D0 → 7F0, 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, 5D0 → 7F3, and 5D0 → 7F4, respectively, characteristic of transitions of Eu3+ ions. It is noteworthy that the Eu complex has a dual-emission luminescence due to its not very efficient sensitization process for energy transfer from the ligands to the Eu3+ ions.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Properties

The luminescence excitation and emission spectra of the Htpbpc ligand and Eu complex have been measured in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure S6, the free Htpbpc ligands show a broad emission peak around 490 nm (λex = 338 nm), which can be ascribed to the π → π* transitions. Furthermore, the 1D Eu complex displays bright magenta luminescence under UV irradiation; as shown in , Eu complex exhibits an obvious peak with a maximum value at 414 nm besides Eu characteristic peaks upon excitation at 343 nm. Comparing with the emission for free Htpbpc ligand, there is a blue shift of approximately 76 nm, which can be belong to the ligand to ligand charge transfer. Besides, the luminescence spectra display five emission peaks at 580, 592, 618, 653, and 698 nm corresponding to the 5D0 → 7F0, 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, 5D0 → 7F3, and 5D0 → 7F4, respectively, characteristic of transitions of Eu3+ ions. It is noteworthy that the Eu complex has a dual-emission luminescence due to its not very efficient sensitization process for  energy transfer from the ligands to the Eu3+ ions.

elements.content: On the basis of the excellent luminescence stability of the Eu complex in broad pH regions and in water system, it has been investigated as a potential fluorescent sensor for metal ions. Furthermore, a series of luminescence-based experiments was studied and is shown in . Interestingly, whether we added monovalent, divalent, or trivalent metal ions (K+, Na+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Zn2+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Ba2+, Cu2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Al3+) into the suspension of Eu complex, the luminescence intensities did not have any significant changes. Nevertheless, the bright red fluorescence was completely quenched when a certain amount of Cr3+ ions was added in the system, implying that the Eu complex can be regarded as a hopeful candidate for selective probing of the Cr3+ metal ion. The inset of a shows the strong red emission of the suspension and addition of other M n+ which could be easily captured by the naked eye under a 365 nm UV lamp, and its brightness disappeared with higher concentrations of Cr3+ addition. In order to evaluate the sensitivity of the Eu complex toward Cr3+ metal ion, varying concentrations of Cr3+ ions were added into the suspension of Eu complex and the luminescence spectra were monitored. With increasing concentration of Cr3+ ions, the luminescence intensities gradually decreased and the emission peak had an obvious red shift. The limit of detection is calculated by 3δ/S, where δ is the standard deviation of the blank measurement and S is the slope of the calibration curve. The calculated detection limit of the Cr3+ ion is 3.64 ppm. Furthermore, the quenching effect can be analyzed by the Stern–Volmer equation: I 0/I = 1 + K SV[Q]. The values of I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities initially and after addition of Cr3+ ions, respectively. [Q] is the concentration of the Cr3+ ion, and K SV is the Stern–Volmer quenching constant. As shown in d, the Stern–Volmer quenching curve for Cr3+ ion is nearly linear at low concentration with a linear fit correlation coefficient of 0.992 and a Stern–Volmer value of 5.14 × 102 M–1. The plot deviates from linearity with the concentration increased (Figure S8a), demonstrating the concurrence of both static and dynamic mechanisms. This is further proved by the fluorescence lifetime measurement (Figure S9); with the concentration increasing, the decay lifetimes were decreased slightly. In addition, the highly sensitive and selective sensing of Eu complex for Cr3+ ion stimulated us to further study the influences of other cations on Cr3+ ion sensing abilities. A 1 mg amount of complex was dispersed in 1 mL of water and ultrasonic treatment to obtain the suspension. Exhilaratingly, the luminescence intensity had no change after adding 200 μL of each metal ion (ion concentration 1 × 10–1 M) except the Cr3+ ion in the suspension of the Eu complex, while the luminescence intensity was nearly complete, disappearing once 200 μL of the Cr3+ ion was introduced. Results indicate that the Eu complex can be highly selective and sensitive with quantitative sensing Cr3+ ion in water. To our knowledge, few fluorescent complexes acting as sensors for Cr3+ ion in water system have been observed in the literature.

Metal Ions Detection

On the basis of the excellent luminescence stability of the Eu complex in broad pH regions and in water system, it has been investigated as a potential fluorescent sensor for metal ions. Furthermore, a series of luminescence-based experiments was studied and is shown in . Interestingly, whether we added monovalent, divalent, or trivalent metal ions (K+, Na+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Zn2+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Ba2+, Cu2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Al3+) into the suspension of Eu complex, the luminescence intensities did not have any significant changes. Nevertheless, the bright red fluorescence was completely quenched when a certain amount of Cr3+ ions was added in the system, implying that the Eu complex can be regarded as a hopeful candidate for selective probing of the Cr3+ metal ion. The inset of a shows  the strong red  emission of the suspension and addition of other M n+ which could be easily captured by the naked eye under a 365 nm UV lamp, and  its brightness  disappeared with higher concentrations of Cr3+ addition. In order to evaluate the sensitivity of the Eu complex toward Cr3+ metal ion, varying concentrations of Cr3+ ions were added into the suspension of Eu complex and the luminescence spectra were monitored. With increasing  concentration of Cr3+ ions, the luminescence intensities gradually decreased and the emission peak had an obvious red shift. The limit of detection is calculated by 3δ/S, where δ is the standard deviation of the blank measurement and S is the slope of the calibration curve. The calculated detection limit of the Cr3+ ion is 3.64 ppm. Furthermore, the quenching effect can be analyzed by the Stern-Volmer equation: I 0/I = 1 + K SV[Q]. The values of I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities  initially and after addition of Cr3+ ions, respectively. [Q] is the concentration of the Cr3+ ion, and K SV is the Stern-Volmer quenching constant. As shown in d, the Stern-Volmer quenching curve for Cr3+ ion is nearly linear at low concentration with a linear fit correlation coefficient of 0.992 and a Stern-Volmer value of 5.14 × 102 M-1. The plot deviates from linearity with the concentration increased (Figure S8a), demonstrating the concurrence of both static and dynamic mechanisms. This is further proved by the fluorescence lifetime measurement (Figure S9); with the concentration increasing, the decay lifetimes were decreased slightly. In addition, the highly sensitive and selective sensing of Eu complex for Cr3+ ion stimulated us to further study the influences of other cations on Cr3+ ion sensing abilities. A 1 mg amount of complex was dispersed in 1 mL of water and ultrasonic treatment to obtain the suspension. Exhilaratingly, the luminescence intensity had no change after adding 200 μL of each metal ion (ion concentration 1 × 10-1 M) except the Cr3+ ion in the suspension of the Eu complex, while the luminescence intensity was nearly complete, disappearing once 200 μL of the Cr3+ ion was introduced. Results indicate that the Eu complex can be highly selective and sensitive with quantitative sensing Cr3+ ion in water. To our knowledge, few fluorescent complexes acting as sensors for Cr3+ ion in water system have been observed in the literature.

elements.content: The quenching mechanism of the Eu complex in the presence of Cr3+ metal ion can be assigned to two primary reasons: First, the emission spectra of Eu complex were covered by the UV–vis absorption spectra of the Cr3+ ion solution, while other metal ions did not have an obvious absorption peak (Figures S10 and S13). In other words, the Cr3+ ion can adsorb the emission light of the Eu complex, hence decreasing the luminescence intensities. Second, three N atoms from three pyridyl rings of each tpbpc– ligand are free to the Eu­(III) ions and thus spaciously decorating the 1D to 3D framework as free-standing donors, which may providing open Lewis base sites for additional metal ions. The further interaction between the terminal Lewis basic nitrogen atoms and the guest Cr3+ ion causes the π → π* transition absorption band to move to longer wavelength, hence minimizing the energy transfer from the tpbpc– ligands to Eu­(III) ions and attenuating the fluorescence intensity at the same time.
elements.clean_text: The quenching mechanism of the Eu complex in the presence of Cr3+ metal ion can be assigned to two primary reasons: First, the emission spectra of Eu complex were covered by the UV-vis absorption spectra of the Cr3+ ion solution, while other metal ions did not have an obvious absorption peak (Figures S10 and S13). In other words, the Cr3+ ion can adsorb the emission light of the Eu complex, hence decreasing the luminescence intensities. Second, three N atoms from three pyridyl rings of each tpbpc- ligand are free to the Eu(III) ions and thus spaciously decorating the 1D to 3D framework as free-standing donors, which may providing open Lewis base sites for additional metal ions. The further interaction between the terminal Lewis basic nitrogen atoms and the guest Cr3+ ion causes the π → π* transition absorption band to move to longer wavelength, hence minimizing the energy transfer from the tpbpc- ligands to Eu(III) ions and attenuating the fluorescence intensity at the same time.

elements.content: Meanwhile, the effects of different sodium salts water solutions of Na y X (X = F–, Cl–, Br–, I–, SO4 2–, CO3 2–, NO3 –, OAc–, SCN–, NO2 –, PO4 3–, CrO4 2–, Cr2O7 2–) on the fluorescence intensities of Eu complex were explored. Results show that different anions have negligible effects on the fluorescence intensity, whereas addition of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– ions can quench the fluorescence rapidly. The inset of a shows that the obvious luminescence quenching response for Cr­(VI) ions of the suspension compared with other anions, which can be captured by the naked eye easily under a 365 nm UV lamp irradiation. To investigate the ability of selective detection by the Eu complex for CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– ions under the existence of other anions, we prepared a mixture of anions solution except CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– ions, as shown in b; the fluorescence intensity had no obvious change in the presence of other anions. Nevertheless, the red light disappeared immediately when CrO4 2– or Cr2O7 2– ions were introduced in the system. Furthermore, the sensitivity experiments were implemented by the titration method with addition of 1 × 10–2 M CrO4 2– or Cr2O7 2– ions water solution to the suspension of Eu complex (1 mg of complex in 2 mL of water). The emissive responses were monitored; as expected, rapid and high fluorescence quenching with significant spectroscopic variation were observed with the gradual addition of Cr­(VI) (CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2–) anions solution. In addition, the Stern–Volmer plots for CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– ions are linear at low concentration (c–f), with a correlation coefficient of 0.9992 for CrO4 2– and 0.9946 for Cr2O7 2–. The Stern–Volmer constants, K SV, are calculated to be 4.85 × 103 and 1.04 × 104 M–1, respectively. By a ratio of 3δ/S, the calculated detection limits of CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– anions even reach as low as 0.33 and 1.07 ppm, respectively. Additionally, the Eu complex can be regenerated for four cycles via centrifuging the suspension after detecting CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– anions and washing several times with deionized water (). Studies of the recyclability and complete quenching effect of CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– ions when the concentration is 10–3 M indicate that the Eu complex is a very smart probe for CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– ions. The PXRD patterns of the Cr­(III)- and Cr­(VI)-ion-treated samples were recorded and are shown in Figure S11, which agreed well with the as-synthesized sample, indicating the retained crystallinity of Eu complex after ion-sensing experiments. In one word, the 1D Eu complex acts as an excellent fluorescent sensor for chromium ions in different valences and exhibits better performance in response time (in seconds) and detection limit. Specifically, a comparison of other MOF-based fluorescent sensors for Cr­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions sensing is listed in Table S3.

elements.content: To investigate the mechanism for the profound quenching effect of Cr­(VI) anions, the UV–vis spectra of each anion in aqueous solution were recorded (Figure S12). It is obvious that the excitation spectrum of the Eu complex was totally overlapped by the absorption spectra of CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– anions, whereas no other anions have overlapped with this wavelength range. In other words, the CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– anions can adsorb the excitation energy of the Eu complex, hindering the efficiency of energy transfer from the tpbpc– ligands to the Eu­(III) ions of the frameworks, thereby decreasing or even quenching the luminescence intensities. Moreover, the fluorescence lifetime measurements prove that the decay lifetimes of CrO4 2–/Cr2O7 2–-treated samples have no significant change compared with that of the initial Eu complex (Figures S14 and S15). In the case of CrO4 2– and Cr2O7 2– anions, the fluorescence quenching only accords with a static mechanism.

In other words, the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions can adsorb the excitation energy of the Eu complex, hindering the efficiency of energy transfer from the tpbpc- ligands to the Eu(III) ions of the frameworks, thereby decreasing or even quenching the luminescence intensities. Moreover, the fluorescence lifetime measurements prove that the decay lifetimes of CrO4 2-/Cr2O7 2--treated samples have no significant change compared with that of the initial Eu complex (Figures S14 and S15). In the case of CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions, the fluorescence quenching only accords with a static mechanism.

elements.content: The fluorescence-based test papers were designed to make the detection experiments simple and convenient. For detection for Cr3+, CrO4 2–, and Cr2O7 2– ions in water, the test paper was soaked in different Cr ions aqueous solutions with different concentrations for 1 min and then dried in air. Take the Cr3+ ion for example, under irradiation of UV light of 365 nm, the fluorescent colors of the test papers changed from bright red to dark red, faint dark green, and finally black as soaked in 10–4, 10–3, 10–2, and 10–1 M of Cr­(NO3)3 aqueous solution (Figure S16). The corresponding fluorescent-based test paper experiments of Eu complex after immersion into different metal ions (1 × 10–2 M) and anions (1 × 10–3 M) aqueous solutions is shown in Figure S17. To the naked eye, one can distinguish the colors obviously. Therefore, the Eu complex and its luminescence-based test paper may develop practical applications in the laboratory and daily life in the near future.

elements.content: In summary, a novel 1D Eu–MOC has been successfully synthesized, which further expands to a 3D H-bonded supramolecular network. The Eu complex not only possesses excellent water stability, pH stability, and thermostability but also can be considered as a superior luminescence sensor for quantitative detection of Cr­(III) and Cr­(VI) ions with high selectivity and sensitivity. In addition, the sample can be regenerated simply and quickly, exhibiting excellent recyclability for detection of CrO4 2– or Cr2O7 2– ions. To our knowledge, this Eu complex is the first MOC material which can realize the rapid detection of noxious chromium ions in different chemical valences in aqueous solution. Exhilaratingly, a luminescence-based test paper of the Eu complex was prepared easily using this complex, and its response to Cr3+, CrO4 2–, and Cr2O7 2– ions in seconds was visible to the naked eye. All results indicate that the Eu complex may potentially be regarded as a multiresponsive luminescence-based sensor for quantitative and highly sensitive detection of chromium-containing wastewater. It is of great significance to develop the potential application of a luminescence-based sensor to environmental areas.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a novel 1D Eu-MOC has been successfully synthesized, which further expands to a 3D H-bonded supramolecular network. The Eu complex not only possesses excellent water stability, pH stability, and thermostability but also can be considered as a superior luminescence sensor for  quantitative detection of Cr(III) and Cr(VI) ions with high selectivity and sensitivity. In addition, the sample can be regenerated simply and quickly, exhibiting excellent recyclability for  detection of CrO4 2- or Cr2O7 2- ions. To our knowledge, this Eu complex is the first MOC material which can realize the rapid detection of noxious chromium ions in different chemical valences in aqueous solution. Exhilaratingly, a luminescence-based test paper of the Eu complex was prepared easily using this complex, and its response to Cr3+, CrO4 2-, and Cr2O7 2- ions in seconds was visible to the naked eye. All results indicate that the Eu complex may potentially be regarded as a multiresponsive luminescence-based sensor for  quantitative and highly sensitive detection of chromium-containing wastewater. It is of great significance to develop the potential application of a luminescence-based sensor to  environmental areas.

cln_elements.content:
In addition, the adjacent 1D chain is further interconnected by the O–H···N hydrogen bonds, resulting in generation of a 3D H-bonded supramolecular network, . This structure has two 1D open parallelogram channels with approximate dimensions of 15.83 × 10.67 and 13.56 × 10.77 Å2, respectively, and these 1D channels are occupied by free DMF and water molecules. The effective free volume is 6% of the crystal volume analyzed by PLATON. Noticeably, the coordination mode of CO3 2– plays an important role in the extension of the 1D chain structure, and the O–H···N H bonding makes a major contribution to expand the 1D to 3D structure.

Thermal Properties

To identify the stability of the 1D complex, TGA measurement has been carried out under N2 protection and is shown in Figure S3. The weightlessness curve has three distinct parts. First, the weight loss of 7.70% (calculated 7.77%) from 115 to 190 °C is due to the loss of unordered water and its internal DMF molecules. Second, the weight loss of 2.87% (calculated 3.08%) in the temperature range between 345 and 410 °C corresponds to the loss of four coordinated water molecules. Finally, the structure begins to collapse from 460 °C and does not stop until heating to 1100 °C, owing to decomposition of tpbpc– ligands, and the ultimate residue can be assigned to formation of Eu2O3. On the basis of the calculation, there are approximately six guest water molecules in the structure.
